美艶仙女香といふ，坂本氏の製する白粉の名の高きに美人をよせて 白粉に花の香のある美人かな 東西庵南北

{Bien-sennyokō} (famous powder) produced by Sakamoto, made for beauties:
{Bien-Sennyōkō to yū, Sakamoto shi no sei suru oshiroi no nadakaki ni bijin wo yosete}

(Her face powder is
scented with floral fragrance.
How beautiful she is!)

{Oshiroi ni
Hana no ka no aru
Bijin kana}

by Tōzai-an Nanboku
markings: censor seal: 極 {kiwame}; publisher seal: {Izumiichi}; artist\'s seal
medium: Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper
portfolio: From Senjokō Face Powder (Bien Senjokō 美艶仙女香)
text:
By the early 19th century, the ideal of popular beauty had changed from the graceful and sweet round-faced types favored by artists like Kiyonaga, Utamaro, and Eishi to more assertive personalities. Artists like Eisen and Kunisada were in the vanguard of this new style, depicting women who appear worldly, reckless, and even slightly dangerous.
This half-length portrait exemplifies Eisen’s vision of women with sharper features, longer faces and noses, elongated eyes, and pouting lower lips. The woman holds a mirror in one hand while she applies makeup with a brush. Her lower lip is green, a popular fashion in the early 19th century. This image is from a five-print series advertising a face powder.
title: Putting on Face Powder
